Congressman Dan Donovan (NY-11) released the following statement regarding his support for, and House passage of, S. Con. Res. 3, which clears the way for repealing Obamacare:    “Obamacare has burdened hardworking Americans with soaring premiums and deductibles, canceled policies, and limited choices. Today’s resolution is the first step in bringing relief to millions of families impacted by our broken healthcare system. I promise to work with my colleagues – on both sides of the aisle – to deliver a real solution that provides quality and affordable healthcare. As we move forward, you can rest assured that there will be a stable transition period to ensure continuous access to health coverage, while the replacement plan is instituted. New Yorkers and all Americans deserve better, and I look forward to putting in place reforms that will create a working and stable healthcare system.”  Following today’s vote, Congress will begin to working on a reconciliation bill that provides the budget framework necessary to repealing and replacing Obamacare.

Proud to announce that the Checkpoint Safety Act, legislation that I'm an original cosponsor of, was reintroduced in Congress this week. This bipartisan bill would require the deployment of an armed law enforcement officer within 300 feet of each security checkpoint at our nation’s largest airports. The tragedy in Fort Lauderdale just this month was an unfortunate reminder that our airports – used by millions of Americans everyday – continue to be top targets for violent attacks. We must commit to taking action to prevent these types of incidents, and this bill is essential to bolstering security and deterring terrorists. I hope Congress will act quickly to pass this common sense measure.   More information on the bill here: http://bit.ly/2ky2fJt

I'm honored to be reappointed Chairman of the House Subcommittee on Emergency Preparedness, Response, and Communications, which has jurisdiction over anti-terror policies. It’s an incredible opportunity and a remarkable privilege to chair a subcommittee that’s so important to the security of New York City and the country. I’m grateful to Chairman Michael McCaul for entrusting me once again with this position. I plan to hit the ground running -- with an aggressive hearing and legislative agenda -- to deliver policies that protect our nation and improve disaster recovery.

Today is International Holocaust Remembrance Day and the 72nd anniversary of the liberation of Auschwitz. On this day, we pause to honor the millions of innocent lives - especially the more than 6 million Jewish victims - lost during the Holocaust, pay tribute to the survivors, and pledge to never forget.

We are and should continue to be a compassionate nation, but we must balance our compassion with security interests. The FBI director said to the Homeland Security Committee, on which I sit, that we cannot properly vet people from war-torn countries, and we know ISIS uses refugee flows to infiltrate the West. Recent attacks in Europe, including deadly events in Paris, highlight how terrorists use the refugee crisis to cross borders undetected and execute heinous acts.   It's critical to understand that this executive order is a pause - not a permanent ban - while we work to ensure that the proper checks are in place to protect our nation from terrorists. However, I'm dedicated to ensuring that this order does not wrongly impact those who have valid visas and green cards. Additionally, I support exploring safe zones in the region to protect innocent life and stabilize conflicted nations. The safety and protection of our country remains my number one priority.

The safety of NYC and the nation depends on the strength of our safety and preparedness measures, and I look forward to helping pass these bills today.

The U.S. House of Representatives just unanimously passed three of my Homeland Security Committee bills -- The Securing Cities Act of 2017, Transit Security Grant Program Flexibility Act and the Cyber Preparedness Act. We have to be constantly vigilant and ensure that law enforcement officials have the resources necessary to prepare for and respond to terror threats. My bills will bolster nuclear, cyber, and transit defenses, and ultimately make the homeland safer. On Thursday, the House of Representatives will vote on the American Health Care Act. It's a major proposal that will impact almost everybody in the country and reform a multi-trillion-dollar industry. As part of my analysis of this legislation, I've received input from local hospitals, doctors, insurers, community health centers, unions, community leaders and residents throughout the district. Based on an in-depth analysis and their valuable feedback, I have deep and serious concerns about the current bill. I plan to meet with President Trump tomorrow to discuss those concerns in detail.

That is why I will vote no on the American Health Care Act (AHCA). I do not believe the legislation as currently written is in the best interest of the 740,000 people I represent in Congress, and I believe we can do better.

Today, I reintroduced the Comprehensive Fentanyl Control Act, legislation that focuses on saving lives by combating fentanyl, a synthetic opioid that is 50 times more powerful than heroin. I had the pleasure of visiting the National Urban Security Technology Lab (NUSTL) – which researches, develops, and evaluates technologies for law enforcement officers and first responders – earlier this week. It’s about time we met North Korean aggression with strength. The President’s fundamental priority is defending the homeland, and Kim Jong-Un’s provocations and disregard for human life are destabilizing the entire region. I support the President’s posture along with the steady hand of his new Chief of Staff, General Kelly, as the Administration navigates a situation that’s the result of years of appeasement. My office is in touch with Staten Island residents Theresa DePaolo and Michael Reilly who contacted my office after finding a Purple Heart medal near Bloomingdale Road and Ramona Avenue, and we are working hard to find the family of its rightful owner. I sent a letter urging the Department of Education to investigate the donation of millions of dollars in grants to U.S. colleges and universities from the Alavi Foundation, an organization which a federal jury ruled was operating as an Iranian front group. Reports allege that the funds were used to hire professors with views supportive of the Iranian regime, a state sponsor of terrorism. It's alarming to think that a rogue nation might have illegally attempted to subvert American academic institutions, and an investigation is necessary to learn about the details of the donations, including whether they impacted the hiring of professors or curricula taught.

Here on Staten Island and Brooklyn, we all unfortunately know or have heard of families whose lives have been devastated by the opioid abuse epidemic. It’s estimated that more than 1,300 lives were lost to drug overdoses in New York City last year alone, and these types of statistics are rising at an alarming rate in communities across the country. We need a comprehensive strategy to combat this deadly crisis, and I support President Trump’s decision to declare this situation a national emergency. While we won’t be able to win this battle overnight, I’m confident that this announcement will prioritize efforts to help those struggling with addiction, as well as stopping the supply of drugs coming into our country. Whether it’s the introduction of my legislation to breakdown fentanyl drug networks, getting New York to participate in the federal prescription data-sharing network, or securing funding for drug education and treatment programs, I look forward to continuing my work in Congress to implement policies that save lives and end this epidemic.

The hatred and senseless violence seen in Charlottesville this weekend was sickening, and I support the DOJ’s recently announced investigation into this act of domestic terrorism. The idea that one race or religion is superior to another is not only reprehensible, it goes against the freedoms and ideals America stands for. As a nation, we must come together to confront intolerance and re-affirm our commitment to combating bigotry, racism, white supremacy, and hate of all forms. My thoughts are with Charlottesville and all those affected by the attack, especially the family of Heather Heyer who was tragically killed while fighting against discrimination and intolerance, as well as the two police officers who tragically passed away from a helicopter crash while monitoring the incident.

Labor Day is in recognition of the American worker. From the industrial revolution to the Internet age, the American worker's grit, innovation, and productivity has powered progress in our country and the world.   The labor movement also allowed folks like my father, who was a longshoreman, to receive a fair day's wage for a fair day's work.  Thank you to all of the men and women whose labor may not make headlines every day, but whose work ethic and drive are the engine of American progress.

We are in the midst of peak hurricane season, and a storm can strike at any time. If the devastation of Superstorm Sandy, as well as the recent destruction caused by Hurricane Harvey, taught us anything, it’s the importance of being prepared. Take time to build a kit, make a plan, and prepare your family for hurricanes and other emergency situations. Learn more: https://www.ready.gov/

“Natural disasters have no boundaries, and it’s an American responsibility to stand with our neighbors in their time of need. In the past week, people from across the nation – including an outpouring of support from Staten Islanders who have donated to and organized relief drives – have come together to help those who’ve been left with nothing in the wake of Hurricane Harvey. Today, Congress built on these selfless actions by swiftly passing an initial disaster relief package that will give families, businesses, and communities the resources they need to move forward in the recovery process. New Yorkers know all too well the widespread devastation hurricanes bring and the long and tough road to rebuilding ahead. Together, with the hard work of President Trump, congressional leadership, first responders and volunteers, our nation will continue working to ensure that Texas and Louisiana is able to recover and rebuild stronger than before. Several obstacles presented themselves in New York City’s recovery effort following Superstorm Sandy, some of which could have been avoided if the post-Sandy bill had been crafted differently. I’ll continue sharing New York’s experiences with my colleagues in Congress”

I’m proud to see that Amazon will be building its first New York based fulfillment center right here on Staten Island. This development will bring thousands of new, good-paying jobs to our community and support the growth of our local economy. It’s clear that Amazon recognized Staten Island’s strategic location, hardworking workforce, and opportunities for continued success when making their decision, and I couldn’t agree more with their choice. The strength of America’s private sector has always been the engine of our nation’s growth, and this project is a clear example of that. I will continue working in Congress to implement tax and regulatory relief that strengthens business opportunities, creates more jobs, boosts wages, and improves the lives of Staten Islanders and Brooklynites, as well as all Americans.

I had the honor of presenting Brooklyn resident Nancy Lewis with a flag that was flown over the U.S. Capitol Building to recognize her late uncle, U.S. Marine Private Joseph C. Carbone. Private Carbone, who served in the 2nd Marine Division during WWII, was killed in the line of duty during the Battle of Tarawa in Japan. More than 1,000 American soldiers were lost during the encounter and his remains were never identified or returned home. Fortunately, Ms. Lewis never gave up hope of bringing closure to her family and reached out to the Marines years late to find out more information. A DNA test eventually identified that he had been unknowingly laid to rest at the National Memorial Cemetery of the Pacific. After nearly 75 years, Pvt. Private Carbone made the ultimate sacrifice for our freedom, and I hope you will join me in honoring his memory. http://bit.ly/2ioQWaG

As many of you know, I chair the House Subcommittee on Emergency Preparedness, Response, and Communications, which shares jurisdiction over FEMA and disaster response. I spent today in Puerto Rico with military and FEMA officials reviewing the ongoing recovery effort down there.   There are great people doing incredible work, but the island was absolutely devastated and no place was spared. They're in need of continuing short-term response and a long-term recovery plan. Debris has been cleared enough to allow access to urban areas, but the mountains are still tough to reach. There have been hundreds of air drops, but getting food, water, and medical supplies to remote areas is an ongoing effort.   Getting the electrical grid up and running is essential. Most of the energy right now is by generator, but that's not a long-term solution. The Army Corps of Engineers is working to get the grid repaired, and they've ordered 50,000 utility poles plus thousands of miles of cables.   I'm glad I had the chance to see the response first-hand, and the devastation our community experienced five years ago was at the front of my mind. I hope they can avoid the problems we're still experiencing in our years-long recovery.   Disaster victims should contact FEMA directly, but anybody with family down there who thinks my office can be of assistance is more than welcome to give me and my staff a call.

I wanted nothing more than to vote for a tax plan that would put more money in the pockets of overburdened taxpayers and spur job creation. However, the bill that came out of the conference committee still means a tax increase for many Staten Island and Brooklyn residents. My priority always has and will continue to be the people of Staten Island and Brooklyn who sent me to Congress to represent them. Their interests come before Washington, always.  For months, I’ve been fighting tooth and nail, together with Republican Reps. Peter King, Lee Zeldin, John Faso, and Elise Stefanik to protect the state and local tax deduction. Capping this deduction – which has been a part of the U.S. tax code since 1913 – will increase taxes and harm the already-unaffordable housing market in my district. Former President Ronald Reagan didn't eliminate SALT when he had the chance in 1986 due to conservative principles, and we shouldn’t remove it now. Additionally, analyses show that New York’s share of the country’s tax burden will grow by 9 percent – the largest increase of any state in the nation. Even this small capped deduction of $10,000 will be eliminated in 8 years, and once it’s gone it probably will be eliminated forever.  We’ve taken our case to Congressional leadership, the public, and directly to the President. Sometimes that fight has been heated, but that’s our job: to look out for the families in our districts who are already living paycheck to paycheck. Our efforts resulted in some positive developments, like the protection of student loan interest and medical expense deductions, but it still falls short of accomplishing the goals that I strongly believed we could and should have achieved.  With the state and local tax deduction nearly eliminated, this tax bill doesn't equal relief for far too many New Yorkers. It is still paid for by the middle-class families of Staten Island and Brooklyn. New York is a high-tax state, and this legislation should serve as a wakeup call to politicians who have been taxing and spending with little regard for the taxpayer. But that still doesn't make it right to penalize people even more. My responsibility and allegiance is to the people who sent me here, and I will not support a tax hike on the people I represent.

Learn more about my vote to defend Staten Island and Brooklyn families. While I support comprehensive tax reform to help jump start the economy, grow jobs, and lower the burden on hardworking families, this bill did not provide the relief Staten Islanders and Brooklynites need and deserve. New Yorkers shouldn’t be subsidizing tax cuts for the rest of the nation. I could never support legislation that raises taxes on hardworking NY-11 residents, which is why I voted no. Your interests will always be my top priority.
